oops:Pitfall.oops:Name: Creating unconnected ontology elements
oops:Pitfall.oops:Description: Ontology elements (classes, object properties and datatype properties) are created isolated, with no relation to the rest of the ontology.

oops:Pitfall.oops:Name: Missing annotations
oops:Pitfall.oops:Description: This pitfall consists in creating an ontology element and failing to provide human readable annotations attached to it. Consequently, ontology elements lack annotation properties that label them (e.g. rdfs:label, lemon:LexicalEntry, skos:prefLabel or skos:altLabel) or that define them (e.g. rdfs:comment or dc:description). This pitfall is related to the guidelines provided in [5].

oops:Pitfall.oops:Name: Missing disjointness
oops:Pitfall.oops:Description: The ontology lacks disjoint axioms between classes or between properties that should be defined as disjoint. This pitfall is related with the guidelines provided in [6], [2] and [7].

oops:Pitfall.oops:Name: Missing domain or range in properties
oops:Pitfall.oops:Description: Object and/or datatype properties without domain or range (or none of them) are included in the ontology.

oops:Pitfall.oops:Name: Inverse relationships not explicitly declared
oops:Pitfall.oops:Description: This pitfall appears when any relationship (except for those that are defined as symmetric properties using owl:SymmetricProperty) does not have an inverse relationship (owl:inverseOf) defined within the ontology.

oops:Pitfall.oops:Name: Equivalent classes not explicitly declared
oops:Pitfall.oops:Description: This pitfall consists in missing the definition of equivalent classes (owl:equivalentClass) in case of duplicated concepts. When an ontology reuses terms from other ontologies, classes that have the same meaning should be defined as equivalent in order to benefit the interoperability between both ontologies.

oops:Pitfall.oops:Name: URI contains file extension
oops:Pitfall.oops:Description: This pitfall occurs if file extensions such as ".owl", ".rdf", ".ttl", ".n3" and ".rdfxml" are included in an ontology URI. This pitfall is related with the recommendations provided in [9].

oops:Pitfall.oops:Name: No OWL ontology declaration
oops:Pitfall.oops:Description: This pitfall consists in not declaring the owl:Ontology tag, which provides the ontology metadata. The owl:Ontology tag aims at gathering metadata about a given ontology such as version information, license, provenance, creation date, and so on. It is also used to declare the inclusion of other ontologies.
